texts.shortText:
Whelks of the genus Burnupena can be difficult to identify, as several species may be common on the same shores, there is considerable variation in shell shape and colour within some species and external features may be concealed by encrusting algae or bryozoans.

This species is probably the most common Burnupena in the intertidal and has a relatively thin shell with a short spire (spire much shorter than aperture) that has only traces of spiral ridges in Western Cape specimens (those in Eastern Cape may have more obvious ridges). The interior of the aperture is deep purple.
Shell up to 45 mm long, typically 35 mm.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.

This is probably the most common of the Burnupena species and occurs relatively high in the shore. Mostly found concealed in crevices or under rocks and sometimes partially buried in sand. Becomes active and gathers quickly around dead of damaged animals or other food materials on which it scavenges.
A scavenger, feeding on a wide range of dead or dying organisms, abandoned bait and fish guts and the like.

The egg cases are compressed, with a leaf-like flap at the apex and are laid in a hemispherical mass attached in the open directly on the rock or to the shells of other molluscs. The eggs hatch directly into crawling young.

Several related species of Burnupena occur on the same shores and can be difficult to separate. This species is best recognized by its short spire, lack of external ridges and deep purple interior. Can be confused with the Ridged burnupena B. cincta, but that species is larger and heavier with pronounced ridges on the shell and a paler purplish interior. Also occurs along with the Papery burnupena B. papyracea, but in that species live individuals are easily recognized as the shells are coated by the purple to orange knobbly bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum. Dead shells are yellow with fine spiral ridges.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 194)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 95).
